sen.j: 山号 釈迦山（しゃかさん）
sen.e: Sango: Shakasan
Sango: Shakasan
Sango (literally, "mountain name," which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple): Shakasan

sen.j: 宗派 天台宗
sen.e: Religious school: The Tendai sect
Religious school: The Tendai sect
Religious school: The Tendai sect
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 本尊 十一面観音
sen.e: Honzon (principal object of worship at a temple): Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy)
Honzon (principal object of worship at a temple): Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy)
Honzon (principal object of worship at a temple): Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy)

sen.j: 創建年 伝・推古天皇14年（606年）
sen.e: The year of the foundation: It is said to be in 606.
Founded in: 606.
Founded in: 606
sen.cmt: ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 開基 伝・聖徳太子
sen.e: Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding): It is said to be Prince Shotoku.
Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding): Prince Shotoku.
Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding): Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 正式名
sen.e: The formal name
Formal name
Formal name

sen.j: 別称
sen.e: Another name
Another name
Another name

sen.j: 札所等 湖東三山
sen.e: Fudasho (temples where amulets are collected): The three mountains in Eastern Biwa Lake
Fudasho (temples where amulets are collected): The three mountains in Eastern Biwa Lake
Fudasho (temples where amulets are collected): The three mountains in Eastern Biwa Lake
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 文化財 本堂、絹本着色日吉山王曼荼羅図他3件（重要文化財）百済寺境内（史跡）
sen.e: Cultural assets: Hondo (main temple), Color on silk painting of Hie Sanno mandala (Mandala having to do with Hie Sannosha Shrine) (絹本着色日吉山王曼荼羅図), three other cultural assets - Important Cultural Property, the precinct of Hyakusai-ji Temple - historic site

Cultural assets: Hondo (main temple), Color on silk painting of Hie Sanno mandala (Mandala having to do with Hie Sannosha Shrine) (絹本着色日吉山王曼荼羅図), three other cultural assets - Important Cultural Property, the precinct of Hyakusai-ji Temple - historic site

Cultural assets: Hondo (main temple), Color on silk painting of Hie Sanno mandala (Mandala having to do with Hie Sannosha Shrine), three other cultural assets - Important Cultural Property, the precinct of Hyakusai-ji Temple - historic site
sen.cmt: (絹本着色日吉山王曼荼羅図)削除しました。

sen.j: 百済寺（ひゃくさいじ）は、滋賀県東近江市にある天台宗の寺院。
sen.e: Hyakusai-ji Temple is a temple of the Tendai sect, located in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
Hyakusai-ji Temple is a temple of the Tendai sect, located in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
Hyakusai-ji Temple is a temple of the Tendai sect, located in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号を釈迦山と称する。
sen.e: Its Sango is Shakasan.
Its Sango is Shakasan.
Its Sango is Shakasan.

sen.j: 本尊は十一面観音、開基（創立者）は聖徳太子とされる。
sen.e: The Honzon is Eleven-faced Kannon and the Kaiki is Prince Shotoku.
The Honzon is an Eleven-faced Kannon and the Kaiki is Prince Shotoku.
The Honzon is an Eleven-faced Kannon and the Kaiki is Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 金剛輪寺、西明寺 (甲良町)とともに「湖東三山」の1つとして知られる。
sen.e: It is known as one of the three mountains in Eastern Biwa Lake together with Kongorin-ji Temple and Saimei-ji Temple (Kora-cho).
It is known as one of the three mountains in Eastern Biwa Lake together with Kongorin-ji Temple and Saimei-ji Temple (Kora-cho).
It is known as one of the three mountains in Eastern Biwa Lake together with Kongorin-ji Temple and Saimei-ji Temple (Kora-cho).

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 琵琶湖の東、鈴鹿山脈の西山腹に位置する。
sen.e: It is located on the east side of Lake Biwa, the west mountain side of the Suzuka mountain range.
It is located on the east side of Lake Biwa, the west mountain side of the Suzuka mountain range.
It is located on the east side of Lake Biwa, the west mountain side of the Suzuka mountain range.

sen.j: 寺伝によれば、推古天皇14年（606年）、聖徳太子の建立という。
sen.e: According to the temple history, it was built by Prince Shotoku in 606.
According to the temple history, it was built by Prince Shotoku in 606.
According to the temple history, it was built by Prince Shotoku in 606.

sen.j: 聖徳太子は当時来朝していた高麗（高句麗）の僧・恵慈（えじ）とともにこの地に至った時、山中に不思議な光を見た。
sen.e: Prince Shotoku saw strange light when he visited this location with Eji, a monk of Goryeo (Goguryeo) (kingdom of Korea), who was visiting Japan at that time.
Prince Shotoku saw strange light when he visited this location with Eji, a monk of Goryeo (Goguryeo) (kingdom of Korea), who was visiting Japan at that time.
Prince Shotoku saw strange light when he visited this location with Eji, a monk of Goryeo (Goguryeo) (kingdom of Korea), who was visiting Japan at that time.

sen.j: その光の元を訪ねて行くと、それは霊木の杉であった。
sen.e: He went to see the source of the light and found out it was a sacred tree of Japanese cedar.
He went to see the source of the light and found out it was a sacred Japanese cedar tree.
He went to see the source of the light and found out it was a sacred Japanese cedar tree.

sen.j: 太子はその杉を、根が付いた立ち木のまま刻んで十一面観音の像を作り、像を囲むように堂を建てた。
sen.e: The prince carved a statue of Eleven-faced Kannon on the Japanese ceder without cutting it down and built a temple surrounding the statue.
The prince carved a statue of an Eleven-faced Kannon on the Japanese ceder without cutting it down and built a temple surrounding the statue.
The prince carved a statue of an Eleven-faced Kannon on the Japanese cedar without cutting it down and built a temple surrounding the statue.

sen.j: これが百済寺の始まりであるといい、百済の龍雲寺にならって寺を建てたので百済寺と号したという。
sen.e: It is said to be the beginning of Hyakusai-ji Temple, and the temple was named Hyakusai-ji Temple (百済寺) because it was modeled after the Ryoun-ji Temple in Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) (百済).
It is said to be the beginning of Hyakusai-ji Temple, and the temple was named Hyakusai-ji Temple (百済寺) because it was modeled after the Ryoun-ji Temple in Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) (百済).
It is said to be the beginning of Hyakusai-ji Temple, and the temple was named Hyakusai-ji Temple (百済寺) because it was modeled after the Ryoun-ji Temple in Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) (百済).

sen.j: 百済寺の史料上の初見は11世紀の寛治3年（1089年）であり、聖徳太子創建との伝承がどこまで史実を反映したものかは不明であるが、百済寺という寺号から見て、この寺は渡来系氏族の氏寺として開創された可能性が高い。
sen.e: According to its historical materials, Hyakusai-ji Temple first appears in the 11th century, 1089, therefore, it is unknown how much the legend of Prince Shotoku founding the temple reflects the historical facts, however, by seeing its jigo (literally, "temple name") - Hyakusai-ji Temple (百済寺), this temple was most likely to be built as a Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory) for a clan formed by immigrants to ancient Japan.

According to historical materials, Hyakusai-ji Temple first appears in the 11th century, 1089, therefore, it is unknown how much the legend of Prince Shotoku founding the temple reflects the historical facts, however, by seeing its jigo (literally, "temple name") - Hyakusai-ji Temple (百済寺), this temple was most likely to be built as a Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory) for a clan formed by immigrants to ancient Japan.

According to historical materials, Hyakusai-ji Temple first appears in the 11th century, 1089, therefore, it is unknown how much the legend of Prince Shotoku founding the temple reflects the historical facts, however, by seeing its jigo (literally, "temple name") - Hyakusai-ji Temple, this temple was most likely to be built as a Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory) for a clan formed by immigrants to ancient Japan.

sen.j: 平安時代には、近江国の多くの寺院と同様、比叡山延暦寺の勢力下に入り、天台宗の寺院となっている。
sen.e: In the Heian Period, as many other temples in the Omi province, Hyakusai-ji Temple also fell within Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei and became a temple of the Tendai sect.
In the Heian Period, as many other temples in the Omi province, Hyakusai-ji Temple also fell within Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei and became a temple of the Tendai sect.
In the Heian period, as many other temples in the Omi Province, Hyakusai-ji Temple also fell within Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei and became a temple of the Tendai sect.

sen.j: 平安時代から中世にかけて、かなりの規模をもった寺院だったようだが、明応7年（1498年）の火災で全焼し、その数年後の文亀3年（1503年）の兵火でも焼け、この2回の火災で創建以来の建物ばかりでなく、仏像、寺宝、記録類なども大方焼けてしまった。
sen.e: Although, seems like, the temple had been quite substantial from the Heian Period to medieval, it was completely-burned by the fire in 1498 and also by the fire caused by war in 1503; not only the original building from its founding but also most of the Buddha statues, the temple's treasure and the records were burned down.

Although it seems like the temple had been quite substantial from the Heian Period to the medieval period, it was completely-burned by the fire in 1498 and also by the fire caused by the war in 1503; the temple's treasure and the records were burned down, which included not only the original building from its inception but also most of the Buddha statues,
sen.cmt: "had been quite substantial from the Heian Period to the medieval" doesn’t make sense
sen.e: Although it seems like the temple had been quite substantial from the Heian period to the medieval period, it was completely-burned by the fire in 1498 and also by the fire caused by the war in 1503; the temple's treasure and the records were burned down, which included not only the original building from its inception but also most of the Buddha statues, the temple's treasure and the records.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ補足しました。スペース削除しました。用語統一しました。

sen.j: さらに天正元年（1573年）には織田信長の焼き討ちに遭い、またも全焼している。
sen.e: In 1573, the temple was burned down again by the fire attack of Nobunaga ODA.
In 1573, the temple was burned down again by Nobunaga ODA.
In 1573, the temple was burned down again by Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 当時、この地に勢力をもっていた佐々木氏の一族六角氏は、観音寺城の支城である鯰江城（なまずえじょう）を百済寺の近くに築いていた。
sen.e: At that time, the Rokkaku clan who was kin to the Sasaki clan, influential around this area, had Namazue-jo Castle, a branch castle of Kannonji-jo Castle, near Hyakusai-ji Temple.
At that time, the Rokkaku clan who was kin to the Sasaki clan, and influential in the area, had Namazue-jo Castle, a branch castle of Kannonji-jo Castle, near Hyakusai-ji Temple.
At that time, the Rokkaku clan who was kin to the Sasaki clan, and influential in the area, had Namazue-jo Castle, a branch castle of Kannonji-jo Castle, near Hyakusai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 信長は自分と敵対していた佐々木氏に味方するものとして、百済寺を焼き討ちした。
sen.e: Nobunaga burned down Hyakusai-ji Temple because he thought that the temple was a behalf of the Sasaki clan who was against Nobunaga.
Nobunaga burned down Hyakusai-ji Temple because he thought that the temple was on the side of the Sasaki clan who opposed Nobunaga.
Nobunaga burned down Hyakusai-ji Temple because he thought that the temple was on the side of the Sasaki clan who opposed Nobunaga.

sen.j: 本堂をはじめ現在の建物は近世以降の再興である。
sen.e: Its Hondo and other buildings remaining today were built after modern times.
Its Hondo and other buildings remaining today were built after modern times.
Its Hondo and other buildings remaining today were built after modern times.

sen.j: 山門を入り参道を進むと本坊の喜見院があり、そこから石段を上ったところに仁王門、さらに上ったところに本堂が建つ。
sen.e: Passing through its Sanmon gate (temple gate) and going down the Sando (an approach to the temple), you will see Kimi-in Temple, Honbo (a main living quarter priest), and going up the stone steps farther, you will see Nio-mon Gate (Deva gate) and there is Hondo after going up more steps.

Passing through its Sanmon gate (temple gate) and going down the Sando (an approach to the temple), you will see Kimi-in Temple, Honbo (a main living quarter priest), and going up the stone steps farther, you will see Nio-mon Gate (Deva gate) and further up is Hondo.

Passing through its Sanmon gate (temple gate) and going down the Sando (an approach to the temple), you will see Kimi-in Temple, Honbo (a main living quarter priest), and going up the stone steps farther, you will see Nio-mon Gate (Deva gate) and further up is Hondo.

sen.j: 参道両側には石垣を築いた僧坊跡があり、かつては多くの建物が軒をつらねていた。
sen.e: There are remains of the Sobo (Monks' lodging house), surrounded by stone walls, on the both side of the Sando and there used to be many buildings standing in a row.
Here you can see the remains of the Sobo (Monks' lodging house), surrounded by stone walls, on both sides of the Sando where there used to be many buildings standing in a row.
Here you can see the remains of the Sobo (Monks' lodging house), surrounded by stone walls, on both sides of the Sando where there used to be many buildings standing in a row.

sen.j: 国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: It is set down as a national historic site.
It is considered to be a national historic site.
It is considered to be a national historic site.

sen.j: 本堂は、入母屋造、檜皮（ひわだ）葺き。
sen.e: Its Hondo is built with Irimoya style (building with a half-hipped roof) and Hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).
Its Hondo is built according to the Irimoya style (building with a half-hipped roof) and Hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).
Its Hondo is built according to the Irimoya style (building with a half-hipped roof) and Hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).

sen.j: 江戸時代初期、慶安3年（1650年）の再興である。
sen.e: It was rebuilt in the early Edo period, in 1650.
It was rebuilt in the early Edo period, in 1650.
It was rebuilt in the early Edo period, in 1650.

sen.j: 中世以来の密教仏堂の形式を残しつつ細部には近世的特質の現われた建築で、2004年に重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The building has the form of the Esoteric Buddhism hall from medieval and the characteristics of modern times in its details at same time; it was set down as an Important Cultural Property in 2004.
The building has the form of the Esoteric Buddhism hall from medieval times and the characteristics of modern times in its details; it was set down as an Important Cultural Property in 2004.
The building has the form of the Esoteric Buddhism hall from medieval times and the characteristics of modern times in its details; it was set down as an Important Cultural Property in 2004.

sen.j: 元来の本堂は現在地の裏手にあり、規模も大きかった。
sen.e: The original Hondo used to be located on the back of its present location and the size was larger.
The original Hondo used to be located in the back of its present location and the size was larger.
The original Hondo used to be located in the back of its present location and the size was larger.

sen.j: また、旧本堂の右方（南）には五重塔が建っていた。
sen.e: Also, There used to be a five-storied pagoda standing on the right side (south) of the original Hondo.
Also, there used to be a five-storied pagoda standing on the right side (south) of the original Hondo.
Also, there used to be a five-storied pagoda standing on the right side (south) of the original Hondo.

sen.j: 重要文化財
sen.e: Important Cultural Property
Important Cultural Property

sen.e: Kondo-karakusamon-kei (Buddhist ritual gong with arabesque design) (金銅唐草文磬)
